definition: (of a ship) to set sail/(of an aeroplane) to take off/also written 啟航|启航[qi3 hang2]

to rise/to raise/to get up/to set out/to start/to appear/to launch/to initiate (action)/to draft/to establish/to get (from a depot or counter)/verb suffix, to start/starting from (a time, place, price etc)/classifier for occurrences or unpredictable events: case, instance/classifier for groups: batch, group

sentences.english: Could all that talk of the Golden Company sailing west have been a feint?
sentences.chinese: 那些關於黃金團向西起航的傳言難道是聲東擊西？

sentences.english: They cleared the ship and were ready to start the voyage.
sentences.chinese: 他們爲這艘船結了關，準備起航。

sentences.english: He is like wearing a sheep, sheep sheep set sail under the south.
sentences.chinese: 身穿羊裝喜樂羊，羊帆起航下南羊。

sentences.english: I folded you into the creases and then, as the sun was setting, I set the fleet to sail.
sentences.chinese: 我將你折進重重褶縫，日落時分，我令艦隊起航。

sentences.english: But it was great that we all rose above it and got out there and started playing again.
sentences.chinese: 但是我們全體將士都拼搏向上，並重新起航走出陰霾。

sentences.english: To sail the Zhuo, Zhuo in the dream of sailing.
sentences.chinese: 希望在濯中揚帆，夢想在濯中起航。

sentences.english: Thery set sail with the first fair wind.
sentences.chinese: 他們在開始順風時起航。

sentences.english: You need passion to get you started.
sentences.chinese: 你需要激情來使你起航。

sentences.english: Come on, snap to and make sail. You know how this works.
sentences.chinese: 快點，拔錨起航，你們知道怎麼做的。

sentences.english: When a ship sails it sets off on its trip.
sentences.chinese: 船起航意味着它開始了某次航行旅程。

sentences.english: Yandry pulled up the anchor, slid one of the long poles off the cabin roof, and pushed them off.
sentences.chinese: 楊恩德里升起錨，從艙頂拖下一根長杆然後起航了。

sentences.english: He'll sail from the harbor tomorrow morning.
sentences.chinese: 翌早上他將從港口開拔起航。

sentences.english: They take their boat out every day at dawn.
sentences.chinese: 他們每天黎明時起航出海。

sentences.english: The river, a hanging Bai Fan raised, standby.
sentences.chinese: 江面上，一掛掛白帆揚起，待命起航。

definition: (of a ship) to set sail/(of an aeroplane) to take off/also written 起航[qi3 hang2]
to set sail on a voyage to a distant place/(fig.) to undertake a great mission
to travel a great distance by sea or air/voyage/long-haul flight
to set out on a journey
to get ready (for a journey)/ready and waiting
(of a boat) to reach the shore/to pull toward shore/close to shore/landfall
lit. to ride the wind and crest the waves/to be ambitious and unafraid (idiom)
